Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research - COSEE Florida: Water as Habitat
Award.AbstractNarration:
Because the state of Florida has over 1,350 miles of salt-water coastline, the state represents a significant, untapped opportunity for the Centers for Ocean Science Education Excellence (COSEE) network to expand its geographic and programmatic reach. Our proposed center, COSEE Florida: Water as Habitat, will build statewide connections with Florida's ocean research community. This project will provide professional development opportunities for scientists to improve their ability to communicate the value and importance of their science to nonscientific audiences and achieve a better understanding of their role in supporting STEM education.

Founding partners for COSEE Florida are the Indian River State College, the Smithsonian Marine Station at Fort Pierce, the Ocean Research & Conservation Association, and the Florida Institute of Technology. Our content theme "Water as Habitat" is engaging and appealing to students and the public and will allow us to place naturally charismatic marine organisms and ecosystems within a systems framework linking physical, chemical and geological ocean processes to biodiversity, marine ecology, climate change, threats to human health, and stewardship actions. COSEE Florida will advance ocean science literacy through the implementation of three strategic initiatives:

1. Professional Development Workshop Series for Scientists: Ocean scientists will participate in workshops to improve their effectiveness in communicating their research to non-scientific audiences. COSEE staff will also provide assistance to scientists who wish to develop quality outreach programs to broaden the impact of their research. Six workshops will be conducted around the state each year.

2. A new Ocean Science Concentration for Pre-Service Educators: Ocean science focused educational content will be added to the Bachelor of Science STEM Education degree for middle school science at Indian River State College in Ft. Pierce, Florida. Students will participate in a suite of courses, research opportunities and high quality practicum situations. The program will be disseminated to additional State College campuses in year 5.

3. COSEE Florida Ocean Science Learning Network: This initiative is the linchpin that brings scientists, educators and the public together to communicate and collaborate. Water As Habitat events will feature ocean-based interactive presentations, educator workshops, and opportunities for continued participant engagement at regional nodes throughout the state. On-line communication tools will be developed to facilitate post-event collaborations and resource sharing. At least five regional Learning Community nodes will be established around the state.


Our work will engage a spectrum of people and organizations from across Florida. Ocean researchers, higher education faculty, informal education institutions, educators and the general public will participate in a wide range of activities. Through our initiatives we will (1) involve up to 90 Florida ocean scientists in effective outreach and education each year, (2) expand the skills and strengthen the ocean science content of at least 200 pre-service undergraduates, 100 in-service teachers and 100 informal educators over a 5 year period, (3) improve the ocean literacy of over 3000 Florida residents and tourists and (4) learn from and contribute to the work of other Centers in the National COSEE Network.

The ocean science content of our programs will draw on current research findings from Florida's leading ocean scientists (Intellectual Merit) and significantly expand public awareness of the significance of their work (Broader Impacts). Scientists will also develop a deeper understanding of the challenges facing STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics) education today (Intellectual Merit) and contribute to improving the quality of teaching and learning in Florida through the integration of cutting edge research into K-16 education (Broader Impacts).

ProgramElement.Text: CENTRES FOR OCEAN SCI EDU EXCE

ProgramReference.Text: CENTRES FOR OCEAN SCI EDU EXCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF award # 1039014 ‘Collaborative Research:  COSEE Florida Water as Habitat’ to the Ocean Research & Conservation Foundation (ORCA) provided funding to work with partners Indian River State College, Florida Institute of Technology, and the Smithsonian Marine Station at Fort Pierce to form the Florida Center for Ocean Science Educational Excellence.  Florida COSEE was the 10th  Regional Center to be funded within NSF’s overall Centers for Ocean Science Education Excellence initiative comprised in 2011 of eleven Centers and one National Network office. NSF’s stated goal for the initiative was to establish a network of coordinated centers that facilitate collaborations and communications between ocean science researchers and educators.

From October 2010 through September 2017, ORCA contributed to the COSEE Florida partnership by

  • creating original education materials (videos and worksheets) designed to help students, educators and the general public develop a better understanding of marine life and the contributions that scientists make to understand the marine environment.
  • providing individualized guidance for Florida ocean and environmental  scientists as they work to develop Broader Impacts plans for their research, infrastructure and STEM education proposals  as required in NSF’s 2010 COSEE Program Solicitation 10-527.
  • administratively managing COSEE Florida Facebook page, website and  Center Advisory Committee meetings and
  • participating in National COSEE Network annual meetings and network working groups.

Instructional Resources:      

Water as Habitat (WaH) videos http://www.coseeflorida.org/water-as-habitat.html.  These fifteen videos engage students with varying interests and provide relevant, real world examples of ocean science research and can be used to teach interdisciplinary STEM concepts across disciplines.   

WaH companion resources. Four of the WaH videos focus on areas of ocean research and exploration where mathematics and engineering concepts are important tools that scientists use every day in their research and exploration work.   To help educators engage students, ORCA has developed teacher instructional guides and student worksheets for these videos.   Aligned with Florida state standards, the materials help math and science educators teach key math concepts and demonstrate that the concepts that they are being asked to learn are relevant to the real world. 

COSEE Science Teachers as Researchers (CSTAR) videos www.coseeflorida.org/cstar.html.   In collaboration with Indian River State College, ORCA helped pre-service science education majors at the College produce videos that showcase their work in COSEE Florida’s Research Experiences for Pre-Service Teachers (REPT) program.  For use in each participant’s future classroom, the videos focus on how science is done and the importance of ocean science.  Four REPT teachers in training worked with ORCA scientists to identify toxic materials in sediments and fish.

Teacher Workshops.  In 2011, Dr. Widder served as the principal instructor for a Deep Sea Biology lecture for 225 people and one-day teacher workshop for 32 educators. Dr. Widder held a bioluminescence in-service teacher training workshop in 2013 for ten educators. To introduce Florida educators to online WaH resources, ORCA conducted a one-day teacher in-service workshop in January 2017 for 18 educators. 

Broader Impacts Guidance:  

ORCA provided 61 ocean scientists and educators with information on NSF’s review criterion #2 that focuses on standards for the Broader Impacts of the proposals submitted to the Foundation. 47 individuals received advice about strategies to develop high quality Broader Impacts plans to complement their scientific work.  The majority were senior and early career professionals (41% and 33%) while 18% were mid-career individuals and 8% were graduate students.   72% were employed at 7 Florida research universities while 5% served as faculty at 2 undergraduate institutions and 15% work at 5 non-academic research institutions in Florida.  An additional 8% are affiliated with collaborating institutions outside of Florida.  Guidance was provided on a range of societally relevant activities including public outreach (online and face- to-face), professional development for K-12 and informal educators, mentoring for undergraduate STEM majors and professional training and career development for ocean science graduate students.

Drawing on a Ten Step strategy presented at five regional workshops and two national professional society meetings, a manuscript is in preparation for submission to Oceanography magazine.  This manuscript reviews ORCA’s broader impacts work and presents a framework that ocean scientists can use to craft quality broader impacts plans for future research and educational projects. 

Administrative Activities:

ORCA handled meeting logistics and travel reimbursement for five meetings of the Center’s eight member external Advisory Committee.  Staff also managed content for the Center’s website and social media pages from 2014-2017 and videotaped nine Smithsonian Marine Station’s Marine Science in the Morning lectures from 2016 to 2017.

Information about ORCA’s WaH instructional resources was disseminated to an audience of over 700 people at two annual National Marine Educators Association (NMEA) conferences. WaH resources will remain available on COSEE Florida’s website and on ORCA’s Kilroy Academy website (http://www.kilroyacademy.org/resources.php). To reach a broader national audience, links to WaH resources are posted on COSEE.net and The Bridge website sponsored by NOAA Sea Grant and NMEA: (http://www2.vims.edu/bridge/search/bridge1output_menu.cfm?q=organizations).

NSF?s stated goal for the initiative was to establish a network of coordinated centers that facilitate collaborations and communications between ocean science researchers and educators.
